sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

row.cell: Item paid for a play on Allhollanday Anno Domini 1605
v li.
Item paid to the Musytyons the same daye
xx s.
Item paid for iiijor staftorches for Revelles the Satterdaye before Candlemas dayeSatterdaye before Candlemas daye: 26 January 1605/6
iiij s.
Item paid for a Play on Candlemas day laste 1605
v li.
Item paid to the Musycions the same daye
xx s.
Item paid to the Musicions for their fee on Alhollandaie 1606
xx s.
I tem paid for 2 staffetorches for the revells on Candlemas Even
ij s.
Item paid for a play on Candlemas Daye 1606
v li.
Item paid to the Musicions for their ffee the same daie
xx s.
Item paid for 4 staff torches for the Revells the same daie
iiij s.
Item paid to Raphe Smyth the Carpenter for pullinge downe the gallery in the hall where the MusiconsMusicons: for Musicionsabbreviation mark missing vse to staund
ij s. vj d.

note.ab: While 'the gallery in the hall where the Musicons vse to staund' is mentioned nowhere else, a 'Mussick Roome' is mentioned in Inner Temple records beginning in 1614–15 (see p 183). These references may be compared to a place for musicians recorded for Lincoln's Inn records beginning in 1632–3 (see p 232, ll.15–16). Musical structures of both Inns are discussed in the Introduction, p xxviii–xxxii.

row.cell: Item paid for the Musitions fee the same daythe same day: All Hallows' Day

div.head: f 64-4v ( 1 November - 1 November) (Payments)

row.cell: Item paid for 2 staffe torches vppon Alhollowday
ij s.
Item paid to the Musicions for their ffee the same day
xx s.

xiij s. iiij d.
Item paid for 2 staffe torches on Candlemas day
ij s. |
Item paid for a play the same day

xx s.

div.note: Antics and puppets, plus the consort, seem to have replaced the customary play on All Saints' Day, due to the ban on the performance of the play.

row.cell: Item payd for 2 staffe torches on Alhallonday
ij s.
Item payd to Musitians for theyr ffee the same day
xx s.
Item payd for a playe the same day
v li.
Item payd to the Musitions for their ffee the vth of November
xiij s. iiij d.
Item payd for a play on Candlemas day
vj li. xiij s. iiij d.
Item payd to another company of players which were appointed to play heere the same day
xxx s.
Item payd for 2 staffe torches the same day
ij s.
Item payd for ye Musitians fee the same day
xx s.
Item payd for one dosen of torches for the Revells in Michaelmas terme 1612
x s.

note.ab: Apparently two different companies were booked for the same afternoon ('another company of players,' p 153, l.14), the second of which did not perform. If so, this is the only instance in the Inner Temple records of a company of players being paid for not performing.

div.head: f 73

row.cell: Item payd for 6 torches for the benchers to see the maske at Elye house
v s.
Item payd for 2 torches another tyme to goe to Item payd for 2 torches another tyme to goe to
ij s.

div.note: No masque is known to have been performed at Ely House, the bishop of Ely's town residence in Holborn, this year. The 'maske at Elye house' (p 153, l.25) was possibly a rehearsal of Beaumont's masque (see Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 3, 235).

div.head: f 75v

row.cell: Item paid to Mr Lewes Hele at 2 seuerall tymes towardes the maske busines
lxx li.
Item paid to Mr ffenner towarde the same busines
x li.
Item paid to a messinger which Mr ffenner provided ‸to fetch Mr Beamont
Item paid to Iohn Hodgkins for boate hyer to and fro to Winchester howse about the maske busines
ij s. vj d.

div.note: Winchester House (p 153, l.39) was the residence of the bishop of Winchester in Southwark. It was from Southwark that the Inner Temple and Gray's Inn masquers proceeded by water to Whitehall, the theme of the masque being the marriage of the Rivers Thames and Rhine.

div.head: f 91v (1 November - 1 November) (Payments)

row.cell: Item payd to the Kinges Maiesties servantes for a play vpon allsaintes day 1614
vj li.

div.note: The phrase 'the Kinges Maiesties servantes' (l.18, see also l.28) is the earliest indication of which playing company performed at the Inner Temple. Under one name or another (including the 'Blackfryers Players' in 1629–30: see p 226, l.40) this company – Shakespeare's company – performed at the Inner Temple from this year forward, and perhaps earlier. But in 1601–2 the same company evidently played at the Middle Temple: see Appendix 6.3, Twelfth Night.

div.head: f 92

row.cell: Item payd for 2 staffe torches the same daye
ij s.

xx s.
I tem payd to his maiesties servantes for a play vpon Candlemas daye last past
vj li. xiij s. iiij d.
Item payd for 2 staffe torches the same day
ij s.
Item payd for ye musitions fee ye same day
xx s.

div.note: The phrase 'the Kinges Maiesties servantes' (l.18, see also l.28) is the earliest indication of which playing company performed at the Inner Temple. Under one name or another (including the 'Blackfryers Players' in 1629–30: see p 226, l.40) this company – Shakespeare's company – performed at the Inner Temple from this year forward, and perhaps earlier. But in 1601–2 the same company evidently played at the Middle Temple: see Appendix 6.3, Twelfth Night.

div.head: f 94v

row.cell: Item payd to the gentlemen reuellars vpon Candlemas day at night
xl s.

div.note: It is not clear exactly what was being reimbursed or rewarded by the payment on f 94v. The round sum would suggest a reward rather than a reimbursement. The spending of domus money suggests that the student revellers performed before an invited audience whom the Inn wished to impress. (See Bulstrode Whitelocke’s description of organizing the revels at Middle Temple 1628-9, pp 223-6.)
